questions.title: Portfolio Management_ An Overview
questions.question:
A key difference between a wrap account and a mutual fund is that wrap accounts:

  1. have assets that are owned directly by the individual.
  2. cannot be tailored to the tax needs of a client.
  3. have a lower required minimum investment.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct . The key difference between a wrap account and a mutual fund is that in a wrap account, the assets are owned directly by the individual. Incorrect. Wrap accounts can be tailored to the tax needs of a client. Incorrect. Wrap accounts have higher required minimum investments. Portfolio Management: An Overview describe mutual funds and compare them with other pooled investment products
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. The key difference between a wrap account and a mutual fund is that in a wrap account, the assets are owned directly by the individual.

  2. Incorrect. Wrap accounts can be tailored to the tax needs of a client.

  3. Incorrect. Wrap accounts have higher required minimum investments.

questions.title: Portfolio Management_ An Overview
questions.question:
Which of the following is least likely true for a separately managed account (SMA) compared with a mutual fund?

  1. Assets are directly owned by the individual.
  2. The minimum investment required to open a SMA is lower than that of a mutual fund.
  3. Transactions can be tailored to the specific tax needs of the investor.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. SMA assets are directly owned by the individual. The investor has control over which assets are bought and sold as well as the timing of the transactions. Correct . The minimum investment required to open a separately managed account is usually much higher than that to open a mutual fund. Incorrect. SMA transactions can be tailored to the specific tax needs of the investor. Portfolio Management: An Overview describe mutual funds and compare them with other pooled investment products
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. SMA assets are directly owned by the individual. The investor has control over which assets are bought and sold as well as the timing of the transactions.

  2. Correct. The minimum investment required to open a separately managed account is usually much higher than that to open a mutual fund.

  3. Incorrect. SMA transactions can be tailored to the specific tax needs of the investor.

questions.title: Portfolio Management_ An Overview
questions.question:
ABC Fund invests in Singapore’s government debt with maturities up to three months. It is most likely classified as a:

  1. fixed-income arbitrage fund.
  2. money market fund.
  3. bond mutual fund.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. A fixed-income arbitrage fund attempts to profit from arbitrage opportunities in interest rate securities. Correct . Money market funds invest in short-term corporate or government debt. The difference between a bond mutual fund and a money market fund is the maturity of the underlying assets. In a money market fund, the maturity is as short as overnight and rarely longer than 90 days. Incorrect. Bond mutual funds hold bonds with maturities as short as one year and as long as 30 years. Portfolio Management: An Overview describe mutual funds and compare them with other pooled investment products
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. A fixed-income arbitrage fund attempts to profit from arbitrage opportunities in interest rate securities.

  2. Correct. Money market funds invest in short-term corporate or government debt. The difference between a bond mutual fund and a money market fund is the maturity of the underlying assets. In a money market fund, the maturity is as short as overnight and rarely longer than 90 days.

  3. Incorrect. Bond mutual funds hold bonds with maturities as short as one year and as long as 30 years.

questions.title: Portfolio Management_ An Overview
questions.question: With respect to the formation of portfolios, which of the following statements is most accurate?

choices.A: Portfolios affect risk less than returns.
choices.B: Portfolios affect risk more than returns.
choices.C: Portfolios affect risk and returns equally.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. As illustrated in the reading, portfolios reduce risk more than they increase returns.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. As illustrated in the reading, portfolios reduce risk more than they increase returns.

questions.title: Portfolio Management_ An Overview
questions.question: With respect to the portfolio management process, the asset allocation is determined in the:
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. The client’s objectives and constraints are established in the investment policy statement and are used to determine the client’s target asset allocation, which occurs in the execution step of the portfolio management process.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. The client’s objectives and constraints are established in the investment policy statement and are used to determine the client’s target asset allocation, which occurs in the execution step of the portfolio management process.

  2. Portfolio construction
  3. Performance measurement
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Security analysis is a part of the execution step of the portfolio management process. Incorrect. Portfolio construction is a part of the execution step of the portfolio management process. Correct . Performance measurement is a part of the feedback step of the portfolio management process. Solution

  1. Incorrect. Security analysis is a part of the execution step of the portfolio management process.

  2. Incorrect. Portfolio construction is a part of the execution step of the portfolio management process.

  3. Correct. Performance measurement is a part of the feedback step of the portfolio management process. The execution step includes asset allocation, security analysis, and portfolio construction.

  3. Incorrect. Under the feedback step, there are two parts: portfolio monitoring and rebalancing and performance measurement and reporting.

questions.question: Which of the following institutions will on average have the greatest need for liquidity?

A is correct. The excess reserves invested by banks need to be relatively liquid. Although investment companies and non-life insurance companies have high liquidity needs, the liquidity need for banks is on average the greatest.

questions.question: A defined benefit plan with a large number of retirees is likely to have a high need for:

Solution

A is correct. Income is necessary to meet the cash flow obligation to retirees. Although defined benefit plans have a need for income, the need for liquidity typically is quite low. A retiree may need life insurance; however, a defined benefit plan does not need insurance.

questions.title: Portfolio Management_ An Overview
questions.question: Which of the following institutional investors is most likely to manage investments in mutual funds?
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Investment companies manage investments in mutual funds. Although endowments and insurance companies may own mutual funds, they do not issue or redeem shares of mutual funds.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. Investment companies manage investments in mutual funds. Although endowments and insurance companies may own mutual funds, they do not issue or redeem shares of mutual funds.

questions.title: Portfolio Management_ An Overview
questions.question: Which of the following investment products is most likely to trade at their net asset value per share?
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Open-end funds trade at their net asset value per share, whereas closed-end funds and exchange traded funds can trade at a premium or a discount.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. Open-end funds trade at their net asset value per share, whereas closed-end funds and exchange traded funds can trade at a premium or a discount.

questions.title: Portfolio Management_ An Overview
questions.question: Which of the following financial products is least likely to have a capital gain distribution?
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. Exchange traded funds do not have capital gain distributions. If an investor sells shares of an ETF (or open-end mutual fund or closed-end mutual fund), the investor may have a capital gain or loss on the shares sold; however, the gain (or loss) from the sale is not a distribution.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. Exchange traded funds do not have capital gain distributions. If an investor sells shares of an ETF (or open-end mutual fund or closed-end mutual fund), the investor may have a capital gain or loss on the shares sold; however, the gain (or loss) from the sale is not a distribution.

questions.title: Portfolio Management_ An Overview
questions.question: Which of the following forms of pooled investments is subject to the least amount of regulation?
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. Hedge funds are currently exempt from the reporting requirements of a typical public investment company.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. Hedge funds are currently exempt from the reporting requirements of a typical public investment company.

questions.title: Portfolio Management_ An Overview
questions.question: Which of the following pooled investments is most likely characterized by a few large investments?
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Buyout funds or private equity firms make only a few large investments in private companies with the intent of selling the restructured companies in three to five years. Venture capital funds also have a short time horizon; however, these funds consist of many small investments in companies with the expectation that only a few will have a large payoff (and that most will fail).

Solution
